projects.title: Procedural Coral Reef
projects.overview: This project is a real-time coral reef I built to explore procedural geometry, lighting, and atmospheric effects. The coral forms are all generated procedurally using parameterized and recursive geometry, which lets me get a wide range of shapes and movement from a small set of reusable systems. I also built a GPU-based particle system to add depth and life to the water.

process.title: Procedural Geometry Systems
process.content:
I implemented all the coral types as C++ classes that inherit from a shared base, which made it easy to apply consistent transforms, coloring, and texturing across different coral forms. The branching coral uses recursive geometry where the radius and length decay with each iteration—I spent a while tuning those decay values to get branches that felt organic rather than too uniform or too chaotic.

The brain coral was a fun one to figure out. I started with a spherical mesh and then modified it with layered sinusoidal noise to get those characteristic ridges and folds. For the barrel sponges, I built a parameterized fin system with controls for ripple, taper, and segmentation—being able to tweak those values and instantly see different sponge variations was really satisfying.

process.title: Lighting, Atmosphere, and Controls
process.content:
Getting the underwater atmosphere to feel right took a lot of iteration. I set up a dynamic lighting system with a rotating light source to simulate the sun moving overhead, which helps sell the sense of being underwater with light filtering down from above. I also added a debug lighting mode so I could inspect geometry without the atmospheric effects getting in the way.

The exponential fog was essential for making the scene feel like it has depth—without it, distant objects looked way too crisp and the scale felt off. I added toggles for fog, particles, and different shading modes so I could quickly compare different configurations while I was developing.

process.title: GPU Particle System
process.content:
I built a custom particle system using VAOs, VBOs, and GLSL shaders to represent suspended matter drifting through the water. Each particle has its own seed value that I use to vary its motion, size, and color over time, which keeps things from looking too repetitive. I went with additive blending and point sprites to get a subtle glow effect—it took some experimentation to find the right balance where the particles add atmosphere without being distracting.

This was my first time implementing a particle system from scratch at the GPU level, and I learned a lot about how to structure the data to keep things performant even with a large number of particles on screen.

projects.title: Reefcraft Water & Fish Shaders
projects.shortDescription: Custom WGSL shaders for water flow and fish schooling visualization.
projects.overview: As part of my technical art internship on the Reefcraft coral visualization project, I developed custom WGSL point sprite shaders for visualizing water flow and animating schools of fish. Starting from pygfx's existing point material pipeline, I extended and modified the shaders to create two visual effects: glowing particles that drift along the currents, and fish-shaped sprites that orient themselves into them.

gallery.alt: School of fish facing into current

process.title: Starting Point: pygfx Point Sprites
process.content: Both shaders began as modifications of pygfx's PointsMaterial pipeline. The existing code handled the vertex shader setup for billboard quads, size calculations across different coordinate spaces, and the binding infrastructure for passing data to the GPU. I kept this foundation and focused my work on the fragment shader.

process.title: Fish Shader: Custom SDF & Billboard Orientation
process.content: The fish shader required more substantial changes. For the shape, I wrote a signed distance function that combines an ellipse (body) with an isosceles triangle (tail) using a smooth union operation. The trickier part was making the fish face into the current by modifying the vertex shader to read a per-vertex yaw angle and orient the billboard quad in world space.

projects.title: Swamp Witch
projects.shortDescription: Character design, SFX makeup fabrication and application.
projects.overview: I created the swamp witch as my final project for the Master Makeup Artist program at The Art of Makeup in Portland, Oregon. She is a culmination of all the skills we learned in the SFX section of the program under the guidance of Thomas Surprenant, which included lifecasting models, character design, sculpting, molding, and casting in different materials, and the application and painting of prosthetic makeup pieces on my model Lindsey.

process.title: Research & Planning
process.content: When planning this project I wanted to make something that showed I could be creative, but also make something realistic and screen-ready. A witch seemed to be a good base character to show these skills, and is a relatively clean slate to work with when building a character alongside the makeup. Sadly my Pinterest inspo board for this project has been lost to time, or I would link it here to show a bit more of my thought process.

process.title: Lifecasting and Sculpting
process.content: The first step in creating a makeup look like this is lifecasting your model. You can sculpt on a generic face, but if you have the opportunity to make something that fits perfectly you should do it.

projects.title: Broken Doll
projects.shortDescription: Shifting character design and makeup application.
projects.overview: I created this makeup as the final project for the hair and beauty section of the Master Makeup Artist program at The Art of Makeup in Portland, Oregon. The project was to create a character that could evolve halfway through the photoshoot, so we would end up with photos of a distinct character with a story that had been told through two different makeup looks. I came up with the idea of a doll that started loved and glowing, and then ended up broken, dirty, and abandoned in a pile of other dolls.

gallery.alt: After shot of doll makeup - broken version

process.title: Process
process.content:
I like to try to push the boundaries of any given assignment, and this one was no different. This being a beauty makeup challenge, I wanted to create a character that was beautiful, but who also had a story to tell, which brought me to the idea of the evolution of a well-loved doll. The model who helped me with this project was very young and so was the perfect fit for this idea, letting me focus on a clean beauty application without needing to do any color correcting or major facial feature changes.

The headpiece helped take this simple concept to the next level, allowing me to demonstrate my fabrication skills as well as my makeup skills. I used a heavy guage wire to create the structure, and thrifted doll heads which I glued to the wire frame. Since the dolls were all made out of different materials it took some trial and error to figure out which glues would work for each one, and I ended up using a combination of hot glue, super glue, and epoxy. One of the dolls had a veil that I wanted to keep, so I had to be careful with the super glue to make sure I didn't burn any holes in it. I also used some spray starch to stiffen the veil so it could be seen in the photos.

For the first makeup, I used a cream Kryolan base, and set it with translucent powder only under the eyes. I added a lot of blush to her cheeks and eyelids, but wanted to keep her skin very plastic looking so didn't use any highlighter. I lightly filled in her eyebrows and added a little bit of mascara, but no eyeliner.

Once we had gotten the first set of photos, it was time to update the look for the second set. I wanted this look to still be rooted in beauty, but take on a more editorial or grunge feeling, so I only changed the makeup a little bit, adding some darker lip gloss that I smeared outside her lip line and a little bit of water mixed with black eyeshadow to add a tear streak down one of her cheeks. I also used some dark brown powder to add dirt to her face, one spot on her forehead and into the creases of her eyes.

projects.title: Lonely Night
projects.shortDescription: Prototype VR environment based on a dream.
projects.overview: Lonely Night is an ongoing project that I started in Mozilla Hubs and later ported in to Unity. Based on a dream I had, it is a VR space that is meant to evoke a sense of loneliness and longing through the imagery of an ongoing party that is impossible to interact with.

projects.title: Mini Monster Hunter
projects.shortDescription: "Inventory" program made for a C++ coding class.
projects.overview: I made Mini Monster Hunter as a final project for my C++ data structures class at Portland Community College. The game is a simple text-based monster inventory, where the player can add their own monsters and then battle them in the arena. This was my first large, multi-file C++ project, and I learned a lot while building it.

projects.title: Fairy Houses
projects.overview: I made these fairy houses as part of a group project for my Design Foundations class, in which we were tasked with creating a pitch for a new monument on campus. We decided to create a hidden fairy garden, where students could go to find a little magic and whimsy. I was responsible for creating the 3D models of the houses, which were inspired by mushrooms and tree houses.
